discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Verified Boot is a security feature in ChromeOS that ensures the integrity of the operating system and firmware. It verifies that the OS and system files have not been tampered with or corrupted during the boot process. If any modification or unauthorized change is detected, the system will attempt to recover to a trusted state. This helps protect the device from malware or unauthorized changes that could compromise its security.

choices.D: Prevents the user from accessing unauthorized websites
choices.A: Makes sure that the firmware and OS have not been tampered with
choices.B: Protects anonymous guests from using the device
choices.C: Eliminates the need for strict policy controls

questions.question_text: What is a feature of Verified Boot?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Feels like A is the one. Thoughts?

choices.C: Allow the installation of the web app from the Chrome Web Store to users within that business unit.
choices.A: Reach out to Chrome Enterprise support and create a ticket to deploy the custom web application to those business users.
choices.D: With the business unit scoped to its own organizational unit (OU), force the installation of the app and extension to your users and browsers via the URL of the web application.
choices.B: Leverage partners to develop software deployment pipelines scoped only to the OU.

questions.question_text:
You have a new, custom, mission-critical web app from your development team. As the ChromeOS Administrator tasked with the deployment of the application to one particular unit, it is decided to leverage ChromesOS in the completing this rollout.

What should you do to support this deployment?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Honestly? I'd go C.

questions.question_text: When using certificates with SCEP, where should an admin install the Google Cloud Certificate Connector?

choices.D: Install to the Google Cloud App Engine
choices.A: On a Windows server connected to the network
choices.C: Root partition of the ChromeOS device

choices.A: Set up a Virtual Private Network (VPN) connection for secure network access
choices.D: Install a firewall on each ChromeOS device
choices.C: Set Restrict users to Auto connect under Networks
choices.B: Unselect Restrict users to Auto connect under Networks

questions.question_text:
A large bank wants all of their ChromeOS devices to auto connect to their managed SSIDs.

How can an admin set a policy for this?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Off the top of my head, Iâ€™d say A.

questions.question_text: You need to verify a device has successfully completed enterprise enrollment in the correct domain. What should you do?

choices.C: Check your inbox for a confirmation email from the domain.
choices.D: Look for the words: The owner of this device is on the background after sign-in.
choices.A: Look for the words: This device is managed by at the bottom of the sign-in screen.
choices.B: Sign in by using a user account associated with the correct domain.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Gut check: D.
